title: Elon Musk keeps laying off Twitter employees after saying cuts were done
description: The latest cuts come as Elon Musk has given the directive to make Twitter ads work like Google search ads, focusing on user’s keyword searches rather than their activity and profile data.
author: Alex Heath

title: The Supreme Court is deciding the future of the internet, and it acted like it
description: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments for Gonzalez v. Google, a case over whether YouTube’s recommendation algorithms should be granted protection under Section 230.
author: Adi Robertson

title: Sonos quietly raises Beam and Sub prices by $50
description: Sonos is increasing pricing for its Beam (Gen 2) and Sub by $50. The products now cost $499 and $799, respectively. The company last raised the prices of numerous products in 2021.
author: Chris Welch

title: When disaster hits, social circles are crucial lifelines
description: Your social network — who’s in it and who you’re close to — can make a difference during a disaster. Research from Flint, Michigan shows how much relationships matter when coping with a crisis.
author: Justine Calma

title: Another podcasting executive is leaving Spotify
description: Parcast founder Max Cutler is leaving Spotify, where he oversaw content partnerships. His departure comes less than a month after podcasting head Dawn Ostroff announced she was leaving.
author: Ariel Shapiro

title: YouTube Music will let make your own custom radio stations
description: YouTube Music’s Radio Builder feature lets you create stations based on artists and customize them with options and filters.
author: Mitchell Clark

title: The classic version of Angry Birds is being delisted from Google Play but renamed on the App Store
description: Rovio Classics: Angry Birds, a rebuilt version of the original mobile hit, will be delisted from Google Play on Thursday, February 23rd. The iOS version will still be available, though its name is set to be changed to Red’s First Flight.
author: Jay Peters

title: How Microsoft’s Nvidia deal works for gamers — with or without Activision
description: Microsoft has signed a 10-year agreement with Nvidia to bring all of its games to the GeForce Now cloud gaming service. Here’s what to expect based on a conversation with Nvidia VP Phil Eisler.
author: Sean Hollister

title: Biden won’t stop a potential ban on importing Apple Watches
description: President Biden has decided to uphold an ITC ruling that may result in an Apple Watch import ban. The dispute centers around medical tech company AliveCor alleging Apple infringed on its EKG patents.
author: Victoria Song

title: Wireless ISP Starry is filing for bankruptcy
description: Starry, an ISP that provides wireless internet service, has filed for bankruptcy after a year of financial troubles. The company says it’ll continue operating and providing internet to customers.
author: Mitchell Clark

title: Microsoft recruited Nintendo and Nvidia to help fight Sony over the Activision deal
description: Microsoft president Brad Smith appeared in Brussels to meet with regulators and make Microsoft’s case to acquire Activision, and it has some surprise muscle in its corner—Nintendo and Nvidia.
author: Tom Warren

title: Microsoft is already undoing some of the limits it placed on Bing AI
description: Testers with access to Microsoft’s Bing AI chatbot were upset with new limits placed on its conversations last week. Now Microsoft has expanded how many chat turns users can take and the total number of chats per day.
author: Richard Lawler

title: Meta is improving Quest hand tracking so you can touch buttons and type on virtual keyboards
description: The MetaQuest v50 update adds a new experimental setting, “Direct Touch,” that will let you “touch” things like menu buttons or virtual keyboards with just your hands.
author: Jay Peters

title: Sony shares details on Gran Turismo 7’s VR mode and 10 new PSVR 2 launch games
description: Sony is sharing new details on Gran Turismo 7’s VR mode and on 10 new PSVR 2 games that will be available within the device’s “launch window.”
author: Jay Peters

title: Microsoft is bringing Xbox PC games to Nvidia’s GeForce Now service
description: Microsoft is bringing its Xbox PC games to rival Nvidia’s GeForce Now cloud gaming service. It’s part of an agreement that may also see Activision Blizzard games on GeForce Now if Microsoft’s Activision deal is approved.
author: Tom Warren

title: Lectric’s new electric cargo bike could be the perfect e-bike for families on a budget
description: Lectric’s XPedition is an electric cargo bike with an attractive price and great looking specs. The bike can carry up to 450lbs of payload and comes with a host of accessories.
author: Andrew J. Hawkins

title: How to turn on Stage Manager on your Mac
description: If you’re using a Mac computer running macOS Ventura, Stage Manager is an alternative way to arrange your apps and tabs that keeps the window you want to focus on front and center. Here’s how to turn it on.
author: Monica Chin

title: Call of Duty content schedule leaked as part of alleged Activision hack
description: Activision Blizzard suffered from an alleged phishing hack that possibly exposed sensitive employee data as well as a content schedule for Call of Duty.
author: Ash Parrish

title: Ikea’s Sonos-powered Symfonisk picture frame speaker is a screaming deal at $65 off
description: The Symfonisk picture frame is like mounting a Sonos One smart speaker on your wall, for less. Plus, discounts on a Samsung G7 gaming monitor, Drop MT3 keycaps, and PlayStation 5 deals, including The Last of Us Part I and Gran Turismo 7.
author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto

title: Bernie Sanders throws support behind striking YouTube Music workers
description: Sen. Bernie Sanders threw his support behind striking YouTube Music workers in a letter addressed to Google CEO Sundar Pichai.
author: Makena Kelly

title: Here’s a $599 cockpit to go with your $1,000 Logitech racing wheel
description: Logitech G teamed up with racing chair company Playseat to create the Playseat Trophy - Logitech G Edition. The fully adjustable cockpit’s made to fit Logitech’s Pro Racing Wheel and Pro Racing Pedals.
author: Emma Roth

title: Building a social media app by yourself is tricky
description: Solo Acts is a five-part series on The Vergecast focused on people independently making really cool stuff on the internet. For the first episode, guest host Ashley Esqueda spoke with Hive Social founder Raluca Pop.
author: Alex Cranz

title: Horror movie production firm Blumhouse launches a gaming division
description: Blumhouse, the production company behind horror movies like Paranormal Activity and M3gan, has launched a video game division for PC, console, and mobile games.
author: Andrew Webster

title: The sporty Beats Fit Pro earbuds now come in three new colors
description: Beats is releasing three new colors of its Beats Fit Pro earbuds on February 23rd. The latest options include blue, coral pink, and a very bright neon yellow. The earbuds remain priced at $199.99.
author: Chris Welch

title: The Supreme Court hears arguments for Gonzalez v. Google, its first big Section 230 case
description: The Supreme Court is hearing oral arguments for Gonzalez v. Google, a case whose plaintiffs seek to hold YouTube liable for recommending terrorist content and potentially narrow Section 230. It will be followed by Twitter v. Taamneh tomorrow.
author: Adi Robertson

title: Researchers will get access to TikTok data — pending company approval
description: TikTok will expand access to its research API to nonprofit academic institutions, providing anonymized public data to researchers studying the platform. It’s the latest in a string of transparency efforts the company is making.
author: Mia Sato

title: Microsoft and Sony square off in EU showdown over Activision and Call of Duty
description: Microsoft, Sony, and others are meeting in Brussels today to discuss the proposed acquisition of Activision by Microsoft. It’s a big meeting that could be a pivotal point for Microsoft’s $68.7 billion deal.
author: Tom Warren

title: Tuesday’s top tech news: A new era (or two) for Sonos
description: We’ve published official images of the Sonos Era 100 and Era 300 smart speakers, and interviewed Shigeru Miyamoto. Plus Microsoft is reminding everyone about its 10-year Call of Duty Nintendo deal.
author: Jon Porter

title: Microsoft signs binding Call of Duty deal with Nintendo ahead of EU Activision hearing
description: Call of Duty will be available to Nintendo players on the same day as Xbox with “full feature and content parity” under a 10-year agreement. Microsoft is due to meet with EU regulators on Tuesday to argue for the acquisition.
author: Jon Porter

title: HBO’s The Last of Us is skipping to the cut scenes, and it's for the best
description: The latest episode of The Last of Us skips some big battles from the video game to tell a more focused story. Yet it feels sort of like cheating to skip the big boss fights and go straight to the emotional gratification.
author: Alex Cranz

title: Sure, why not let an airplane seat electrify my brain?
description: A patent from aerospace company Embraer would pair an emotion-reading face detection camera with a system to offer transcranial electrical or magnetic stimulation during flights.
author: Adi Robertson

title: Social networks’ latest business model is charging for security
description: In the span of three days both Meta and Twitter announce plans to charge people for basic security features. In both instances the plan appears to be to charge people a monthly fee for the security services, in addition to a blue checkmark and other, actually…
author: Adi Robertson

title: Exclusive: these are the new Sonos Era speakers
description: Sonos plans to release two new products, the Era 300 and Era 100, in late March. The Era 300 is designed to produce immersive spatial audio, while the Era 100 will improve upon the company’s current Sonos One speaker.
author: Chris Welch

title: Google Chrome’s latest version includes tools to address its memory hog problem
description: Google has started to roll out new features designed to improve battery life and memory usage for devices running the latest version of its Chrome desktop web browser.
author: Jess Weatherbed

title: Shigeru Miyamoto is working with his hands again
description: Super Mario creator Shigeru Miyamoto talks about the new theme park Super Nintendo World, which just opened at Universal Studios Hollywood in Los Angeles.
author: Andrew Webster

title: Ubisoft will mess with XIM cheaters in Rainbow Six Siege
description: Ubisoft has developed a system to detect players that use third-party hardware to spoof controller inputs in Rainbow Six Siege. It’s rolling out mid-season, and will mess with cheaters input latency.
author: Tom Warren

title: Nobody can stop you from printing circuit boards
description: Ever wanted a super customer keyboard or trackball? It’s shockingly easy to design and make your own PCBs, and in this guide, we walk you through the steps to do it — but you’ll have to learn to solder on your own.
author: Chris Person

title: TikTok wants longer videos for its new creator fund
description: The TikTok Creativity Program is open by invitation only for now, and participants will need to make videos longer than one minute to monetize through the program. The new program is in addition to ad revenue sharing and tips available to creators.
author: Mia Sato

title: Here’s how to secure your Twitter account without paying for Blue
description: Twitter’s making text message two-factor authentication available only to Twitter Blue subscribers starting on March 19th. Here’s how to switch your 2FA method away from SMS before then.
author: Emma Roth

title: ‘Bending physics’: inside Rimac’s plan to make the fastest EV on the planet
description: Mate Rimac’s electric hypercar company has broken speed records and taken on inconceivable projects like the takeover of Bugatti. But the CEO is circumspect about staying in his home country of Croatia and what that will mean for Rimac’s future.
author: Tim Stevens

title: Are those… light strips on the back of OnePlus’ new concept phone?
description: OnePlus is teasing a new concept phone by releasing a couple of images of the “OnePlus 11 Concept” device. It looks a lot like the concept device might come equipped with light strips. It’ll be officially revealed next week.
author: Jon Porter

title: Microsoft’s Outlook spam email filters are broken for many right now
description: Microsoft Outlook spam filters seem to be broken. Many Outlook personal users are spotting lots more email spam in their inboxes this morning.
author: Tom Warren

title: Microsoft Teams is getting big performance improvements next month
description: Microsoft is working on a new Microsoft Teams app that dramatically improves performance on laptops and PCs. The new Teams app will be available in preview initially next month, and should use 50 percent less memory.
author: Tom Warren

title: NBA star Paul Pierce fined $1.4 million for promoting Emax cryptocurrency
description: Former NBA champion Paul Pierce has agreed to pay over $1.4 million in SEC penalties after failing to disclose that he was paid to promote the EthereumMax cryptocurrency to his Twitter audience.
author: Jess Weatherbed

title: Monday’s top tech news: Paid verification comes to Meta
description: Meta is testing letting users on Instagram and Facebook pay to be officially verified, after Twitter rolled out a similar feature under Elon Musk’s ownership last year. Meanwhile, Twitter is removing SMS 2FA for non-paying users.
author: Emma Roth

title: A second Hellboy reboot is officially on the way
description: Hellboy is getting yet another reboot. Hellboy: The Crooked Man will enter production next month in Bulgaria, Deadline reports. The new film will be directed by Brian Taylor, best known for the Jasan Statham action movie Crank.
author: Jon Porter

title: The Steam Deck now supports game transfers from PCs
description: The Steam Deck now gives you the ability to transfer a game to the device from a PC on your local network that already has it installed, saving you from having to download the game again.
author: Emma Roth

title: Meta’s testing $12 per month paid verification on Instagram and Facebook
description: Meta’s testing a new verification subscription on Facebook and Instagram that costs $11.99 per month on web or $14.99 per month on mobile. It’s rolling out in New Zealand and Australia before expanding to more countries.
author: Emma Roth

title: Google Meet rolls out 360-degree virtual backgrounds for video calls
description: Google Meet is launching new 360-degree backgrounds for video calls on iOS and Android. These backgrounds use your phone’s gyroscope to move with you.
author: Emma Roth

title: Diablo IV’s open beta starts next month
description: The open beta for Diablo IV starts on March 24th and will last until the 26th, while those who preordered the game will get early access to the beta from March 17th to the 19th.
author: Emma Roth

title: Starlink’s testing a ‘Global Roaming’ internet service for $200 per month
description: Starlink’s testing a new Global Roaming service that costs $200 per month and provides internet from “almost anywhere on land in the world.”
author: Emma Roth

title: Garmin Vivomove Trend review: trending smarter
description: The $269.99 Garmin Vivomove Trend is a stylish hybrid smartwatch and the company’s first to support Qi wireless. While Garmin is best known for rugged watches, its lifestyle watches have made big strides.
author: Victoria Song

title: WhatsApp’s latest iOS update adds picture-in-picture for video calls
description: WhatsApp is adding support for picture-in-picture mode for iOS. The update should let you switch to other apps while on a video call, and is rolling out in the coming weeks.
author: Emma Roth

title: The AI-powered Seinfeld spoof is set to return to Twitch with new guardrails in place
description: Twitch’s two-week suspension of Nothing, Forever, the AI-powered Seinfeld spoof, is set to lift on Monday. Its creators at Mismatch Media have been working to make sure transphobic comments won’t happen again.
author: Jay Peters

title: Apple, please don’t take all of the buttons away
description: iPhone 15 Pro rumors suggest that Apple will remove the physical volume and wake buttons, replacing them with haptic solid-state buttons. Here’s the thing: please don’t do that, Apple.
author: Allison Johnson

title: The Nintendo Switch OLED is nearly $50 off for President’s Day
description: In honor of President’s Day, eBay is slashing prices on a range of new and refurbished tech, including the Nintendo Switch OLED Model. There are also discounts to be had on Anker’s 637 Charging Station and Apple’s AirPods Max.
author: Brandon Widder

title: Official: Twitter will now charge for SMS two-factor authentication
description: Only Twitter Blue subscribers will get the privilege of using the least secure form of two-factor authentication. If you don’t start paying for Twitter Blue, Twitter will simply turn off your SMS 2FA after March 20th.
author: Sean Hollister

title: Microsoft will limit Bing chat to five replies to stop the AI from getting real weird
description: Microsoft capped Bing AI chatbot conversations at five turns per session after reports of strange and unsettling responses. The company previously said long chat sessions can make it respond in “a style we didn’t intend.”
author: Tom Warren

title: The NBA app is going to let you digitally possess a live player
description: The NBA app is getting a way to overlay yourself on another player in a live game so that it looks like you are that player. The feature is coming to the app sometime in the future.
author: Jay Peters

title: Amazon’s Alexa app gets more Sonos-y with new multiroom audio controls
description: Amazon is bringing more polish to its multiroom audio platform by adding new controls to the Alexa app. These let you easily move music between speakers and see everything playing on your system.
author: Chris Welch

title: Google’s long-awaited Tasks and Reminders consolidation starts in March
description: Google will automatically migrate Google Assistant and Calendar app reminders to Google Tasks in May. Personal account users will be able to voluntarily migrate in March, while Google Workspace enterprise users can do so in April.
author: Sheena Vasani

title: Apple’s first iOS 16.4 public beta has new emoji and push notifications from web apps
description: Apple released iOS 16.4 for public beta testing one day after the developer release. It adds emoji from Unicode 15.0, roman transliteration languages like Urdu, Punjabi, and Gujarati, notifications from web apps, and more.
author: Umar Shakir

title: Ford can’t afford to miss on quality in the EV revolution
description: Ford is the number two seller of electric vehicles, but it is also number one in recalls. The company’s history of struggles with quality is coming under scrutiny, especially as the F-150 Lightning EV is under investigation for battery problems.
author: Patrick George

title: Twitch now lets streamers tag channels in stream titles
description: Twitch will now let streamers tag other channels in their stream titles. It’s a small feature that could be a really useful way for streamers to direct fans to interesting channels.
author: Jay Peters

title: Fortnite now has a Bandcamp radio station
description: Epic Games has just unveiled Fortnite’s new “Radio Underground” station, a collection of songs curated by Bandcamp that features 11 independent artists from around the world.
author: Jess Weatherbed

title: Tile Anti-Theft Mode makes its trackers ‘invisible,’ with a $1 million fine for misuse
description: Tile trackers can become invisible to others in an attempt to keep thieves from finding them on or in users’ valuables. Turning on Anti-Theft Mode requires identity verification and a potential $1 million fine if used for a crime.
author: Umar Shakir

title: M3gan’s unrated cut is coming to Peacock
description: The unrated cut of Universal’s M3gan is coming to Peacock on February 24th to give everyone a chance at seeing how much more messed up the movie could have been.
author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

title: Amazon is the latest company to bring staff back to the office three days a week
description: Amazon employees will be expected to work from the office at least three days per week starting May 1st, CEO Andy Jassy told staff. Companies like Apple and Starbucks have a similar schedule in place.
author: Jay Peters

title: The Marvels is being pushed back to November
description: Nia DaCosta’s The Marvels — now out November 10th — is being pushed back from its original July release date, but its trio of stars looks amazing in a new teaser poster.
author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

title: Roblox is working on generative AI tools
description: Roblox (the company) is developing generative AI tools to help Roblox developers more easily create games and assets. The first two tests of the tools will roll out in the coming weeks.
author: Jay Peters

title: The best tech gifts for under $50
description: Good gifts don’t always have to be expensive. Here, we’ve highlighted smart speakers, streaming devices, gaming accessories, earbuds, and a variety of other tech that’s currently available for less than $50.
author: Sheena Vasani

title: Introducing the AI Mirror Test, which very smart people keep failing
description: The launch of Microsoft’s AI chatbot Bing has captivated users. But too many people believe the bot could be sentient when it only reflects our language back to us. Believing in chatbot sentience is failing the AI mirror test.
author: James Vincent

title: A new mainline Civilization game is in development at Firaxis
description: A new Civilization game, likely to be called Civilization VII, is in development at Firaxis Games, incoming studio head Heather Hazen has announced. It was announced alongside the news that the studio head is leaving.
author: Jon Porter

title: The best Presidents Day sales happening now
description: This Presidents Day features a smattering of excellent tech deals, from smartwatches and earbuds to TVs and laptops. Whether you’re shopping for smart home stuff or gaming deals, there’s probably something for you.
author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto

title: The Verge’s favorite media obsessions
description: We asked the staff of The Verge what their current obsessions were and here are the answers we got, divided into four categories: games, TV series, books, and music.
author: Verge Staff

title: Fitbit adventures, challenges, and open groups are headed to Google’s graveyard
description: Fitbit announced that adventures, challenges, and open groups will no longer be available in its app on March 27th.
author: Victoria Song

title: Ikea’s new air quality monitor lets you keep an eye on pollutants in your home
description: The Vindstyrka is coming in April and can monitor particulate matter levels (PM2.5), humidity, temperature, and total volatile organic compounds (VOC) of your home air. It will also work with Ikea’s Dirigera hub and possibly Matter.
author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy

title: Samsung has created a zero-click antivirus for messages
description: Samsung’s new Message Guard security feature for its Galaxy range of smartphones and tablets can protect users against “zero-click” cyberattacks disguised as image attachments in messages.
author: Jess Weatherbed

title: As conservatives criticize ‘woke AI,’ here are ChatGPT’s rules for answering culture war queries
description: OpenAI has shared some of the internal rules it uses to guide the output of its chatbot ChatGPT. This comes at a time when right-wing commentators claim the company and its AI have “gone woke.”
author: James Vincent

title: Friday’s top tech news: new iOS emoji just dropped
description: The beta version of iOS 16.4 adds a new crop of emoji, the SEC charges another crypto founder with fraud, and Nothing’s debut smartphone finally gets a stable version of Android 13.
author: Allison Johnson

title: The Mate SUV electric cargo bike is coming to replace your expensive car
description: Mate’s first electric cargo bike, the Mate SUV, is scheduled to arrive in the EU and UK this September with a €6,499 (about $6,900) price. That’s still cheaper than the average car that costs over $10,000 a year to operate.
author: Thomas Ricker

title: Tesla denies union-busting claims in Buffalo
description: Tesla says recent layoffs at its Buffalo, New York facility were part of a routine performance review cycle and that it is “false” that it fired employees in response to a new union campaign. It had been accused of retaliation.
author: Jon Porter

title: Good for Nothing: Phone 1’s stable Android 13 release is starting to arrive
description: Nothing’s first mobile device, Phone 1, is getting its first major OS upgrade. Nothing OS 1.5 is the company’s version of Android 13, and it’s starting to arrive as a stable update on devices enrolled in beta testing.
author: Allison Johnson

title: Today is the last day to preorder Samsung’s latest Galaxy devices at a discount
description: Samsung is still offering free storage upgrades, store credit, and other incentives to those who preorder the new Galaxy S23, S23 Plus, or S23 Ultra ahead of their release on February 17th. The same goes for its Galaxy Book3 laptops.
author: Sheena Vasani

title: Microsoft’s Bing AI plotted its revenge and offered me furry porn
description: We prompted Microsoft Bing to split its chat AI into ten different “personalities” which told us wild things, although we’re pretty sure it’s just a big AI hallucination.
author: Sean Hollister

title: Terra founder Do Kwon charged with fraud over its $40 billion crypto crash
description: The SEC is suing Do Kwon for fraud based on claims made about his so-called stablecoin, TerraUSD. Its collapse drained billions in investments and dragged down several other firms in 2021 as “crypto winter” set in.
author: Emma Roth

title: The Nier: Automata anime returns this weekend following covid-related postponement
description: New episodes of Nier: Automata Ver1.1a will air again on Crunchyroll beginning February 18th. Three episodes of the anime have already been released.
author: Jay Peters

title: Apple releases iOS 16.4 developer beta
description: Apple’s first beta for iOS 16.4 is now available and has support for Unicode 15.0 emoji and web app notifications. And roman text can now be used for South Asian languages, including Punjabi, Urdu, and Gujarati.
author: Umar Shakir

title: E3 is ‘full speed ahead,’ even though Ubisoft’s CEO hinted it might not be
description: Ubisoft CEO Yves Guillemot indicated in an investor call that E3 2023 may not actually take place, but the president of ReedPop assures The Verge that planning is still moving forward.
author: Jay Peters

title: iOS 16.4 will let web apps on your homescreen send push notifications
description: Apple’s new iOS and iPadOS 16.4 betas will let Safari web apps on your homescreen send you push notifications. The feature was first announced at WWDC in June.
author: Jay Peters

title: Whoop whoop: the excellent Whoop fitness tracker got more affordable
description: Whoop, a fitness wearable favored by elite athletes, is lowering its prices by $61 for annual subscriptions and $81 for 24-month subscriptions.
author: Victoria Song

title: TwitchCon 2023 says goodbye to San Diego
description: Twitch has announced that Las Vegas and Paris will host the US and EU TwitchCon events in 2023. Last year, TwitchCon returned after being on hiatus for two years in the midst of the covid pandemic.
author: Ash Parrish

title: Tesla recalls 362,758 vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving beta for ‘crash risk’
description: Tesla filed a recall notice for an upcoming software update to Model 3, X, S, and Y vehicles equipped with the Full Self Driving (beta) driver assist feature.
author: Richard Lawler

title: The founder of WallStreetBets is suing Reddit
description: The creator of the WallStreetBets community, Jaime Rogozinski, is suing Reddit over claims he was wrongfully banned as a moderator of the subreddit.
author: Emma Roth

title: Meta is copying Telegram channels in Instagram
description: Meta is introducing its own take on Telegram channels with broadcast channels on Instagram, CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced. They’ll be coming to Messenger and Facebook in the future.
author: Jay Peters

title: Microsoft to support Windows 11 on Apple M1 and M2 Macs through Parallels partnership
description: Microsoft is finally offering official support for Windows 11 on Apple M1 and M2 Macs. You’ll need to run it in a virtual machine, though, as there’s still no sign of native support from Apple.
author: Tom Warren

title: YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki steps down after nine years at the helm
description: YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki is stepping down, she announced Thursday. Neal Mohan, currently YouTube’s chief product officer, will be taking over.
author: Jay Peters

title: Apple’s Tetris movie lines up real history with a retro thriller
description: Tetris will be available to stream on Apple TV Plus on March 31st and stars Taron Egerton in a true story covering the legal battle to secure the titular game’s distribution rights from the Soviet Union.
author: Jess Weatherbed

title: TikTok is launching a $500,000 live trivia contest
description: TikTok is holding daily trivia challenges from February 22nd and 26th and offering a $500,000 cash prize pool to winners. The series will be hosted by James Henry, a popular creator on the platform.
author: Mia Sato

title: John Wick: Chapter 4’s final trailer is a warning not to play in traffic
description: John Wick: Chapter 4 — in theaters March 24th — puts Wick and the Bowery King against a fleet of new assassins and some chaotic traffic in latest trailer.
author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

title: Architectural Silhouettes Play With Perspective in Patrick Akpojotor’s Fragmented Portraits
description: Combining a love for African masks and the people and buildings of his hometown of Lagos, Nigeria, Patrick Akpojotor (previously) merges the figurative details of faces, shoulders, and arms with the geometric forms of hallways, doors, and staircases. “My surf…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Bisa Butler’s Vibrant Quilted Portraits Share Extraordinary Stories of Black Americans
description: “I find myself drawn to photographs that remind me of my grandmother’s photo albums, of aunts and uncles, cousins, and ancestors that I’ve never known,” says Bisa Butler (previously), who stitches swatches of vibrant fabrics into striking, life-size portraits…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Humor and Happenstance Coalesce in Julie Hrudová’s Amsterdam Street Photography
description: Along the streets and canals of Amsterdam, photographer Julie Hrudová (previously) captures daily life through candid snapshots of cyclists hauling unique cargo, pedestrians battling the elements, and canines commuting in style. In her series Chasing Amsterda…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Wild Personalities Flirt With Their Frames in Calvin Nicholls’s Meticulous Paper Sculptures
description: In exacting detail, a giraffe nuzzles its young and a panda noshes on eucalyptus fronds in Calvin Nicholls’s paper sculptures (previously). Working primarily in white and neutral-toned paper, his pieces capture the intricate details of animals’ musculature, f…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Endangered Animals Dissolve and Reassemble in Thomas Medicus’s Anamorphic Glass Sculpture
description: Depending on which direction you approach from, you may encounter a lynx, a bee, a kingfisher, or a river trout in Austria-based Thomas Medicus’s new public installation. Moving around the work, one image gradually dissolves into abstract strips of color befo…
author: Kate Mothes

title: After Sitting in Storage for More Than Three Decades, an Art Amusement Park Is Finally Going On Tour
description: In the summer of 1987, a carnival like no other popped up for thirteen weeks on a public green in Hamburg, Germany. Walking through a gate featuring an oversized painting by Sonia Delaunay, visitors entered the world of Luna Luna, an amusement park brimming w…
author: Kate Mothes

title: A Visit to Third Man Records Reveals the Remarkably Analog Process of Cutting Vinyl Records
description:
﻿
How do our favorite songs make their way into vinyl records? The team over at WIRED visits Third Man Pressing in Detroit to document the particularly labor-intensive production process. From adding the finicky lacquer coating to etching the matrix number by…
author: Grace Ebert

title: The 2023 Underwater Photographer of the Year Contest Dives into the Stunning, Heartbreaking Lives of Aquatic Creatures
description: Dedicated to spotlighting the most vibrant, awe-inspiring aquatic organisms, this year’s Underwater Photographer of the Year competition centers on the mammals, fish, and plants occupying the world’s oceans and seas. The 2023 contest garnered more than 6,000 …
author: Grace Ebert

title: Memory and Knowledge Intertwine in Chiharu Shiota’s Immersive String Installations
description: In Signs of Life, a dense installation of knotted and wound string fills much of Galerie Templon’s New York space. The work of Japanese artist Chiharu Shiota (previously), the solo show transforms the gallery into a monochromatic labyrinth of intricate mesh t…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Vintage Ephemera Backdrops Mark Powell’s Intimate Ballpoint Pen Drawings
description: From playing cards and posters to envelopes and postcards scrawled with notes, the untraditional canvases holding Mark Powell’s artworks are tapestries of memories and experiences past. The Brighton-based artist (previously) sutures scraps of vintage ephemera…
author: Grace Ebert

title: A Staggering 3.32 Billion Celestial Objects Dot an Enormous New Image of the Milky Way
description: A massive new composite released earlier this year reveals a confounding number of stars in the Milky Way. An international collaboration gathered from multiple telescopes at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile, the stunning work captures a stagg…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Interview: Kate MccGwire On Discerning Duality, Connecting with Nature, and Making Art in the Belly of a Dutch Barge
description: Growing up on the Norfolk Broads, a network of waterways in the eastern lobe of England that are mostly navigable by boat, Kate MccGwire explored the area’s wetlands and observed wildlife that would set in motion an artistic practice centered in nature. The a…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Jake Ricker’s Photographs Find the Extremes of Human Emotion on the Golden Gate Bridge
description: Functioning as a tourist attraction and essential form of infrastructure, the Golden Gate Bridge is what photographer Jake Ricker refers to as a “strange paradise.” His ongoing series by the same name focuses on the lighthearted, alarming, and sometimes bizar…
author: Grace Ebert

title: In ‘Walks of Life,’ Migwa Nthiga Photographs the Communities Most Impacted by the Climate Crisis
description: Those living near Lake Turkana in northern Kenya have been experiencing the brunt of the climate crisis. Already a dry, arid region, recurring droughts have left communities without water for animals, crops, and drinking, requiring people to leave their homes…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Mesmerizing Paper Sculptures and Animations by Zai Divecha Convey the Subtlety of Change
description: In Phase Shift, San Francisco-based artist Zai Divecha (previously) translates the illusion of movement to monochromatic paper works. Her solo show, which runs from February 25 to March 25 at Heron Arts, features animations and sculptures that reference early…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Monumental Bubbles Pop Up in Public Spaces in Atelier Sisu’s Inflatable Installations
description: Whether illuminated by the sun or spotlights, the undulating layers of Atelier Sisu’s playful installations are a presence in public spaces. The Sydney-based studio, which is a collaboration between artists Renzo B. Larriviere and Zara Pasfield, celebrates co…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Symmetric Flora and Fauna Converge in Kelly Louise Judd’s Dreamlike Paintings
description: Symmetry and mirroring inform many of Kelly Louise Judd’s paintings, which intertwine flora and fauna in delicate compositions. Ferns overlay the long tails of two cats, a lanky heron gracefully perches among bluebells and sunflowers, and human hands reach up…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Dramatic Landscapes and Dazzling Portraits Highlight Global Perspectives in the 2023 Sony World Photography Awards
description: From the sinuous lines of a leaping cat, to a giant tortoise gliding alongside a snorkeler, to a lone cyclist illuminated on a road juxtaposed against a looming city, the winning images from this year’s Sony World Photography Awards (previously) showcase a re…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Meticulous Folds Form Maze-Like Hallways and Ornate Spaces in Simon Schubert’s Paper Reliefs
description: In Simon Schubert’s intricate folded compositions, bars of sunlight dash across door frames, ornate cornicing, and parquet floors in a complex interplay of geometric forms. Relying exclusively on the way light rakes across the surface of paper, the Cologne-ba…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Vibrant Hybrid Figures Emerge in Lou Benesch’s Spiritual Watercolor Illustrations
description: Fantastic creatures with keen attitudes and fragments of human anatomy occupy the vivid watercolor illustrations of Lou Benesch. From her studio in Paris, the French-American artist visualizes the characters that populate folklore, Greek myths, and classic fa…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Shift Happens: A Forthcoming Book Catalogs the 150-Year History of the Keyboard
description:
What if QWERTY wasn’t the standard keyboard layout? A forthcoming book by Chicago-based designer and writer Marcin Wichary examines the now-ubiquitous format and how it came to dominate modern technology.
Fully funded a few hours after launching on Kickstarte…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Fairytale Scenes Nestle Between the Covers of Isobelle Ouzman’s Altered Books
description: Open one of Isobelle Ouzman’s books, and you’ll be transported to a whimsical world of flora and fauna. The Bratislava-based artist (previously) carves pages of found novels and other tomes into intricate paper labyrinths of forests and meadows. Often occupie…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Anthony Theakston’s Elegant Sculptures Imbue Ceramics and Bronze with Avian Spirit
description: Known as silent predators of the night, owls possess the beguiling ability to swoop within inches of their prey undetected due to specialized feathers that make their flight almost completely inaudible. It’s no wonder that for millennia, the enigmatic creatur…
author: Kate Mothes

title: A Prismatic Installation of LED Lights Mimics a Chameleon’s Color-Changing Scales
description: Hundreds of individual cells shaped like bursting stars comprise a new kaleidoscopic installation by the creative studio SOSO. A project for a San Diego real estate company, “Chameleon Wall” imitates the small reptile by changing color in a dynamic dance of p…
author: Grace Ebert

title: RISD Continuing Education Offers 170+ Online Courses for Adults and Teens
description: Rhode Island School of Design Continuing Education (RISD CE) is thrilled to open registration for over 170 online courses this spring for adults and teens. Programs include online certificates for adult learners, RISD’s pre-collegiate Advanced Program Online,…
author: RISD

title: Explore Hundreds of Exquisite Botanical Collages Created by an 18th-Century Septuagenarian Artist
description: At age 72, Mary Delany (1700-1788) devoted herself to her art practice, taking up a form of decoupage to create an exquisite collection of botanical collages from dyed and cut paper. She interpreted many of the delicate specimens she encountered in Buckingham…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Construction Goes Small Scale with Mini Materials’s Tiny Building Supplies
description: Building a tiny home gains new meaning when working with Mini Materials. The U.S.-based company invites craftspeople and masons to think small for their next projects, offering pallets of cinder blocks and lumber ready to be slathered in mortar or nailed into…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Miniature Ships Sail Atop Asya Kozina’s Extravagant Baroque Wigs of White Paper
description: Artist Asya Kozina is known for her elaborate paper wigs that soar into the air with scenes of miniature metropolises and various botanical frills, coils, and pleats. Referencing the ominous tale of the Flying Dutchman, Kozina’s latest collection transports w…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Join Us for A Colossal Workshop on Playful Character Drawings with Mattias Adolfsson
description: Grab a pen and paper, and join artist Mattias Adolfsson (previously) and Colossal on March 11 for a virtual workshop on small character illustrations. In this one-hour session, Adolfsson will teach students how to draw a few of his signature quirky characters…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Ornate Picture Frames Sprout Twisted Roots in Organic Sculptures by Darryl Cox
description: In Darryl Cox’s organic sculptures, gnarled tree roots or branches merge with the ornate grooves, patterns, and gilding of picture frames. The Bend, Oregon-based sculptor (previously) continues to explore the material possibilities of wood and its relationshi…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Commuters Go Wild in Matthew Grabelsky’s Uncanny Subway Paintings
description: Urbanites know the subway is a prime location to spot the city’s oddities, and yet, a run-in with one of Matthew Grabelsky’s characters would be a particularly wild encounter. The Los Angeles-based artist has spent the last few years rendering human-animal hy…
author: Grace Ebert

title: The Astonishing Biodiversity of Fungi Blooms in Max Mudie’s Macro Photographs
description: “I’m not the first person to say it, and I’m not going to be the last, but when you find out how integral fungi are to our existence, it makes everything else feel insignificant,” says Max Mudie, whose foraging expeditions reveal the otherworldly elegance, di…
author: Kate Mothes

title: February 2023 Opportunities: Open Calls, Residencies, and Grants for Artists
description: Every month, Colossal shares a selection of opportunities for artists and designers, including open calls, grants, fellowships, and residencies. If you’d like to list an opportunity here, please get in touch at hello@colossal.art. You can also join our monthl…
author: Colossal

title: Savor These Decadent Cakes, Pastries, and Other Sweet Treats in the Soft Glow of Candlelight
description: Just like recipes are passed from one generation to the next, so are the methods behind the decadent cakes and pastries of Cereria Introna. Piped with thick pink frosting or dusted with sugar, the confections are handmade in Italy by a family that’s been whip…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Trick Facial Recognition Software into Thinking You’re a Zebra or Giraffe with These Pyschedelic Garments
description: Here’s some unusual criteria to consider when deciding what to wear: if you’re scanned by facial-recognition software, do you prefer being detected as a zebra, giraffe, or a dog? Cap_able, an Italian fashion-meets-tech startup, prompts consumers to consider i…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Interview: A Prison Art Community On the Power of an Annual Exhibition in Michigan to Support More Than 700 Incarcerated Artists
description: As abolitionists and activists fight to end mass incarceration and the horrifying conditions of life in U.S. prisons, individuals and organizations have taken it upon themselves to help those trapped in the unjust system. The Prison Creative Arts Project has …
author: Grace Ebert

title: Lithe Figures Cast in Bronze by Coderch & Malavia Mimic Gracefully Choreographed Movements
description: From their recently relocated studio in Ribarroja de Turia, Valencia, Coderch & Malavia (previously) sculpt dancers and precariously posed figures frozen mid-movement. Swirling locks of hair sweep upward into the air, a long scarf billows sideways in folds an…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Ethereal Light Suffuses Domestic Interiors with Surreal Hues in Alfie Caine’s Paintings
description: Imbued with otherworldly light and a jewel-toned palette, Alfie Caine’s dreamscapes tuck domestic architecture into the idealized surroundings of manicured neighborhoods, country gardens, and lush woodland. The East Sussex-based artist draws on his formal tra…
author: Kate Mothes

title: From Chicago to Detroit, Yashua Klos Presents Black Resilience, Defiance, and Tenderness
description: Chicago continues to rank among the most segregated cities in the United States, with Black and brown populations living across the south and west sides that lack the investment and resources of the white-dominated northern neighborhoods. Caused by more than …
author: Grace Ebert

title: Jennifer McCurdy Harnesses an Island’s Natural Rhythms in Captivating Porcelain Vessels
description: The natural patterns of turning tides and changing seasons illuminate the delicate porcelain sculptures of Martha’s Vineyard-based artist Jennifer McCurdy. Responding to the shifts of island life—and “island time”—she draws inspiration from the surrounding en…
author: Kate Mothes

title: The Block Museum of Art Presents ‘The Heart’s Knowledge: Science and Empathy in the Art of Dario Robleto’
description: What do we owe to the memories of one another’s hearts? This central question resonates throughout the exhibition The Heart’s Knowledge: Science and Empathy in the Art of Dario Robleto jointly presented by Northwestern University’s Block Museum of Art and the…
author: Block Museum of Art

title: Fanciful Characters Inhabit María Jesús Contreras’ Whimsically Illustrated Worlds
description: Fluffy calves with wings and a knack for pollination, picnicking bunnies, and a cow enjoying a grassy meal at the dinner table are a few of the adorable creatures that populate María Jesús Contreras’ illustrations. The Chile-based artist envisions fantastical…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Braids and Bowlers: Indigenous Bolivian Women Skateboard in Style in Celia D. Luna’s Empowered Portraits
description: Against the pastels and earth tones of a skate park in Bolivia, Miami-based photographer Celia D. Luna captures the vibrant energy and determination of women who express solidarity and strength through a love of skateboarding. Part of her series Cholitas Brav…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Whimsical Woodland Creatures and Sea Life Carved by Zoe Feast Inhabit Raw Wood Rounds
description: Designer Zoe Feast has an affinity for patterns, and her practice revolves around motifs of flora, fauna, and organic forms that she creates for a variety of personal projects and commissions. After a visit to her local library and an encounter with its laser…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Folk Art and Bold Geometric Shapes Flourish in Lisa Congdon’s Joyful Paintings
description: A sense of lively optimism permeates Lisa Congdon’s work. Through vibrant palettes of yellows, pinks, and blues, the Portland-based artist pairs bold geometries with folk art symbols, rendering abstract compositions or minimal scenes that capture a joyful out…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Memories Emerge in Stephen Wong Chun Hei’s Paintings as Vivid Saturated Landscapes
description: Vivid palettes of blues, greens, and pink saturate Stephen Wong Chun Hei’s landscapes, which translate memories of travel into dream-like paintings in acrylic. The artist considers each work a vessel for the impressions of places he’s traveled or hiked. “I ne…
author: Grace Ebert

title: Delicate Knots, Velvet, and Beads Entwine in Julia Shore’s Mossy Embroideries
description: Dappled with French knots, glinting materials, and pieces of moss, botanical embroideries by Julia Shore replicate the forest floor’s supple textures in fiber and beads. The Los Angeles-based artist also uses hand-dyed velvet, wool, felt, and sequins to add a…
author: Kate Mothes

title: Vibrant Makeup Mirrors Sweet Frozen Treats in Max Siedentopf’s ‘Pleasure Portraits’
description: London-based artist and creative director Max Siedentopf has a knack for portraying more than meets the eye in his distinctive portraits. A series titled Pleasure Portraits looks forward to summer, featuring the distinctive pastels and jewel tones of ice crea…

title: A New Monograph Follows the Evolution of Wangechi Mutu’s Mythologizing Practice

description: Ever been curious what the temperature and humidity level were in your living room? Well, now the HomePod Mini can tell you.

description: The four-day week is here to stay for companies that took part in a pioneering trial.

description: Boompods is developing products made from plastic dumped on beaches and in the sea.

title: Save $400 on a 16-inch MacBook Pro laptop at Best Buy
description: Apple sales are rare, but this MacBook Pro deal is worth considering if you need to upgrade your aging laptop.
author: Charlie Osborne

title: 重いウェブサイトで訪問者離反と機会損失--Contentsquare報告書
description: Contentsquareの年次報告書によれば、モバイルとデスクトップに異なるユーザー体験環境を融合させることが成約率の鍵になるという。
author: ZDNet Japan Staff

title: CTCと埼玉県横瀬町、「Fitbit」を活用した実証実験--健康意識の向上へ
description: 伊藤忠テクノソリューションズと埼玉県秩父郡横瀬町は、健康意識の向上に向けて、腕時計型のウェアラブルデバイス「Fitbit」を活用した実証実験を実施している。実験期間は、1月4日～3月31日。

title: DXの一環として推進すべき--日本IBM、メタバースの本格普及に向けたレポート発表
description: 日本アイ・ビー・エムは、国内メタバース市場の概況やメタバースが果たす役割を分析し、メタバースサービス提供者に向けた提言をまとめたレポート「過剰な期待に沸くメタバース市場、その先にある真のポテンシャルとは？」を公開した。

title: CTC、メタバース活用の移住相談窓口を地方自治体に提供
description: 伊藤忠テクノソリューションズは地方自治体向けに、メタバース活用の課題や有効性を確認するため、バーチャル空間での移住相談窓口を提供している。地方自治体や移住検討者がアバターを通して、地域の暮らしや各種制度などについて情報交換するコミュニティーとして活用できる。

title: 東急建設、社外秘だった二酸化炭素排出量の算定ツールを公開
description: 東急建設は、積み上げ式で建築資材に製造時に発生する二酸化炭素の排出量を算出するツールを公開した。作業の効率化と算定誤差の最小化を独自の工夫で実現している。

description: NECは2月21日、人工知能（AI）を用いて小売店舗のデジタルトランスフォーメーション（DX）を支援するクラウドサービス「NEC 棚定点観測サービス」の品出し通知機能などを強化したと発表した。

title: Raspberry Pi、デバッグ用プローブを発売
description: Raspberry Pi財団は、「Raspberry Pi Pico」や、「Arm」アーキテクチャーに基づく他のマイクロコントローラー上で実行されているコードのデバッグを可能にするプローブ「Raspberry Pi Debug Probe」を発売した。

description: 電通は2月20日、デジタル販促の効果予測システム「SP COMPASS」の提供を始めた。スマートフォンでキャンペーンに応募し景品やポイントがもらえる「デジタル販促」が注目を集めている。一方で、効率的な分析手法が確立されていないなど参入や継続における課題も顕在化している。

description: マネーフォワードは、デジタル庁が推進する「認定Peppol Service Provider」の認定を受けた。同社は請求書（インボイス）などをオンラインでやりとりするためのグローバルな標準規格である「Peppol」を管理する団体「Open Peppol」に所属している。

title: 「Raspberry Pi」を冷却するには--ヒートシンクの効果を確認してみた

title: 自然現象のデジタルツイン化を支援する新たなコンピューターシステム
description: 人工知能（AI）チップを手掛けるセレブラスシステムズは、米国立エネルギー技術研究所と協力し、流体力学における運動方程式とも言うべきナビエ・ストークス方程式の数値解を高速で求めるシミュレーションを実行した。本記事ではその概要を紹介する。
